sections.summary: The CPI tracks the weighted average price of a basket of consumer goods and services, serving as the benchmark for inflation. The Fed targets 2%, but in the post-COVID world, 'Supercore CPI' (Services excluding Energy and Housing) has become the real battleground.
sections.deep_dive: Traditional CPI is lagging. Housing (Shelter) makes up ~34% of the index but trails real-time rent data by 12 months. In 2026, the focus is on 'AI-flation' (rising cost of compute/energy) versus 'AI-deflation' (collapsing cost of cognitive labor).
sections.council_debate: {"geopolitics": "Deglobalization is inflationary. Reshoring supply chains adds a structural 1-2% rigid cost to CPI that monetary policy cannot fix.", "macro": "The 'Last Mile' of inflation is the hardest. Getting from 9% to 3% was easy (supply chains healing). sections.forecast_risks: Risk of 'Stagflation Lite' where growth slows but CPI sticks at 3.5% due to wage spiraling. Upside risk (for markets, not consumers) is AI productivity driving CPI to 0% despite massive money printing.
sections.gms_conclusion: Neutral View. The components are mixed. Ignore the headline number; focus on Supercore Month-over-Month. If Supercore annualizes >3.5%, remain defensive.
